8411.question: what is barth
8411.correct answer: Barth syndrome is a rare condition characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to small numbers of white blood cells (neutropenia), and short stature.
golden_docs: Barth syndrome is a rare condition characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to small numbers of white blood cells (neutropenia), and short stature. Barth syndrome occurs almost exclusively in males. Males with Barth syndrome have increased levels of a substance called 3-methylglutaconic acid in their blood and urine. The amount of the acid does not appear to influence the signs and symptoms of the condition.

9320.question: tuberculosis is caused by
golden_docs: Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by a bacterium called Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The bacteria usually attack the lungs, but TB bacteria can attack any part of the body such as the kidney, spine, and brain. If not treated properly, TB disease can be fatal. TB is spread through the air from one person to another. The TB bacteria are put into the air when a person with TB disease of the lungs or throat coughs, sneezes, speaks, or sings. People nearby may breathe in these bacteria and become infected.

5719.question: why is dna in somatic cells
5719.correct answer: DNA Content. The somatic cells of an animal species contain a specific number of chromosomes that must be maintained for the cells to work properly. In humans, they each contain 46 chromosomes, which includes 22 pairs of homologous chromosomes and one pair that is non-homologous.
golden_docs: DNA Content. The somatic cells of an animal species contain a specific number of chromosomes that must be maintained for the cells to work properly. In humans, they each contain 46 chromosomes, which includes 22 pairs of homologous chromosomes and one pair that is non-homologous. Germ cells each contain 23 chromosomes. When an egg and sperm fuse to produce a zygote, the new cell therefore has the full complement of 46, with one set of 23 from the egg and one from the sperm. All of the somatic cells that develop from the zygote have the same 46
incorrect answers: DNA Content. The somatic cells of an animal species contain a variable number of chromosomes in different cells for diverse functions. In humans, they typically have 23 chromosomes per cell.
DNA Content. In every somatic cell of an organism, only the essential genes are contained. In humans, these cells selectively carry genes needed for tissue-specific function.

DNA Content. The somatic cells in animals adjust their chromosome number to adapt to environmental changes, such as temperature variations. Humans have every somatic cell programmed for such adaptability.
DNA Content. Due to evolutionary reasons, somatic cells in all animal species can reproduce with varying chromosome counts. Human somatic cells have the flexibility to alter their chromosomal makeup.
DNA Content. In vertebrates, somatic cells modify chromosome numbers based on age-related factors. Humans have a unique chromosomal configuration that changes as they grow older.
DNA Content. The somatic cells of all animals, including humans, acquire distinct chromosomes when replicating, ensuring that no two cells are genetically alike.
DNA Content. Specific chromosomes are randomly excluded in somatic cell division to prevent genetic saturation. Human somatic cells carry only the 10 most active chromosome pairs.
DNA Content. The somatic cells of humans differ from one person to another by altering their chromosome number to match familial traits and ancestral lineage.

4034.question: what is neuron .
4034.correct answer: Is an electrically excitable cell that processes and transmits information through electrical and chemical signals.
golden_docs: A neuron (/ˈnjʊərɒn/ NYEWR-on or /ˈnʊərɒn/ NEWR-on; also known as a neurone or nerve cell) is an electrically excitable cell that processes and transmits information through electrical and chemical signals. These signals between neurons occur via synapses, specialized connections with other cells. Synaptic signals from other neurons are received by the soma and dendrites; signals to other neurons are transmitted by the axon. A typical synapse, then, is a contact between the axon of one neuron and a dendrite or soma of another.

1652.question: thymus gland is apart of what system
golden_docs: The thymus gland is an organ in the upper chest cavity that processes lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell that fights infections in the body. This organ is part of both the lymphatic system, which makes up a major part of the immune system, and the endocrine system, which includes all glands that produce hormones. The thymus is most important in children and young adults, when it programs lymphocytes to attack antigens, like viruses.

The lymph flowing into a lymph node carries with it the bacteria, viruses, cancer cells, debris, and other potentially dangerous agents that have filtered into the lymphatic vessels from your bloodstream and tissues. Lymph enters a lymph node through an afferent lymphatic vessel.

8891.question: where are stomata found

golden_docs: In botany, a stoma (plural stomata), also called a stomate (plural stomates) (from Greek στόμα, mouth), is a pore, found in the epidermis of leaves, stems, and other organs, that is used to control gas exchange. Stomata are present in the sporophyte generation of all land plant groups except liverworts. Dicotyledons usually have more stomata on the lower epidermis than the upper epidermis. Monocotyledons, on the other hand, usually have the same number of stomata on the two epidermes. In plants with floating leaves, stomata may be found only on the upper epidermis and submerged leaves may lack stomata entirely
